importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the jury verdict in the defamation lawsuit against Jack Nicklaus' former business partners.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame spans Nicklaus' initial joining of the Nicklaus Companies in 2007 and the 2025 defamation lawsuit, highlighting the long-term business and personal conflict.

keyTakeAways: Jack Nicklaus, a 85-year-old professional golfer and 18-time major champion, won a $50 million defamation lawsuit against his former business partners, specifically the Nicklaus Companies.
The jury found that the company and its executives spread false stories claiming Nicklaus was joining the LIV Golf League and suffering from dementia, which damaged his reputation.
Howard Milstein and Andrew O’Brien were named as individual defendants, but the jury did not find them personally liable.
The lawsuit originated from claims that Nicklaus was being defamed by false narratives about his health and business intentions, including a $750 million deal with LIV Golf.

Nicklaus had previously left the company in 2007 under a $145 million agreement, and later sought to use his name independently for golf course design, leading to a prior legal dispute over name rights.
The company still holds rights to sell branded clothing and equipment with the 'Jack Nicklaus' logo, while Nicklaus is free to design golf courses under his own name.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Jack Nicklaus, the 18-time major champion golfer, has won a $50 million defamation verdict against his former business partners at the Nicklaus Companies. A jury in Palm Beach County ruled that false claims — including that Nicklaus was joining the LIV Golf League and suffering from dementia — damaged his reputation and exposed him to ridicule and contempt. While Howard Milstein and Andrew O’Brien were named individually as defendants, the jury found no personal liability against them. The case stemmed from a long-standing business dispute over Nicklaus’ right to use his name and image after leaving the company in 2007. Though Nicklaus is now free to design golf courses under his own name, the company retains the rights to use the 'Jack Nicklaus' brand for merchandise.
title: Jack Nicklaus Wins $50 Million Defamation Verdict Against Former Business Partners
